texts.aims: The research aims to collect people's understanding about Soft Skills
texts.estimated: The estimated time to complete the questionnaire is 30 minutes
texts.filling: By filling this research instrument, you agree to permit the researcher to obtain, use and disclose the anonymous information provided as described below.
texts.first-accept: 1. I understand that all information is confidential. I will not be personally identified. I agree to fill this research instrument for research purposes and that the data derived from this anonymous research instrument may be published in journals, conferences and blog posts.
texts.second-accept: 2. I understand that my participation in this research instrument is totally voluntary, and that declining to participate will involve no penalty or loss of benefits. If I choose, I may withdraw my participation at any time. I also understand that if I choose to participate, that I may decline to answer any question that I am not comfortable answering.
texts.third-accept: 3. I understand that I can contact the researcher if I have any questions about this research. I am aware that my consent will not directly benefit me. I am also aware that the author will maintain the data collected in perpetuity and may utilize data for future academic work.
texts.fourth-accept: 4. By starting the questionnaire I freely provide consent and acknowledge my rights as a voluntary research participant as outlined above and provide consent to the researcher to use my information in conducting research on the areas noted above.
texts.study-about: This study is about the perceptions and behaviors of researchers, professionals, and students in the software engineering areas related to soft skills in their experiences.
texts.SE: Software Engineering (SE) is an area that requires several logical abilities (Hard Skills), and, in this way, those kinds of skills were considered the most important in the past. However, nowadays, subjective qualities, as known as Soft Skills (SSs) are as important as the logical ones, because professionals must have the capacity to learn, working in teams, oral and writing skills once the software development is a result of human activities, which often include problem-solving capabilities, cognitive aspects, and social interaction
texts.SE-related: Soft Skills are skills related to human personalities and behaviors rather than technical aptitude or knowledge. For instance, they are skills that determine one's strengths as a leader, facilitator, or negotiator.
texts.hard-skills-are: Hard Skill are the countable skills, it is the knowledge about having a solid foundation in mathematics, sciences, engineering and as well as skills in computer science field just like data structures, numerical analysis, data management, network science or programming languages. They are the techinal qualities an individual can have to perform a task or a job, just as programming languages
texts.the-need: The need for Soft Skills has increased along with Software Engineering evolution. In this perspective, those human skills become an important factor in job requirements [1]. As the projects complexity increases over the years, the human interaction as communicate with teammates or even with clients becomes something common and indispensable. Then, the industry does not require only professionals with Hard Skills but also professionals who have well-developed Soft Skills [2].

instructions.name: Classify
instructions.you-should: After reading the statements carefully, you should DRAG and DROP the cards to split them up into 3 piles:
instructions.pile1: 1. A pile for statements you tend to disagree with;
instructions.pile2: 2. A pile for cards you tend to agree with;
instructions.icon: Click on the move icon to move the statements between piles
instructions.order: The order per pile or the number of statements per pile does not matter
instructions.finish-action: When you quantify all statements, you can click on Continue or click Back to see the last step

instructions.name: Quantify
instructions.you-have: You have to quantify each statement according to your agreement or disagreement degree
instructions.example: For example, you can quantify a statement as -3 for a sentence you disagree the most or 3 you agree the most.
instructions.order: The order you quantify does not matter however as you can see at the top, each classification number has a limit
instructions.finish-action: When you quantify all statements, you can click on Continue or click Back to see the last step

explanation.name: Explain
explanation.text-placeholder: Explain here why you choose the extremes (e.g., -3 or 3, -4 or 4) for this statement

instructions.name: Explain
instructions.you-have: You have to explain the statements you set as the most agreed and most disagreed.
instructions.order: The order to explain does not matter, you just have to click on the arrow to switch to another statement and you must explain all statements
instructions.finish-action: When you explain all statements, you can click on Continue
